Award.AwardTitle: Successful Adoption of Innovation in Engineering Education: Faculty Characteristics and Environmental Perceptions

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This engineering education research project will investigate factors that help or hinder faculty adoption of innovations in engineering education. Specifically, the project seeks to understand relationships between faculty and their work environment in the cases of those who adopt and choose not to adopt innovations. The project will study the current culture in an academic institution to extend theories related to adoption and diffusion of innovations, change management, and attitudinal-behavioral theories to diffusion of engineering education innovations.

The broader significance and importance of this project are to help better disseminate successful educational innovations by understanding the interface between faculty and their work environment. Should the project succeed at lowering barriers to adoption, the results could be transferred to other institutions of higher education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to address a nationwide need to better translate engineering education research—what we know works—into the classroom setting—putting it to work. This project specifically investigated personality characteristics and work environment perceptions of faculty members who do adopt engineering education innovations, and contrasted them with those of faculty members who do not adopt. This work recognizes faculty personality characteristics and work environment perceptions that promote effective adoption, and acknowledges those that may impede successful adoption of engineering education innovations in the classroom. Having a more formal knowledge of personality characteristics and work environment perceptions promotes a realignment of individual and institutional priorities aimed at increasing the number of faculty members successfully adopting engineering education innovations.

We achieved the project goal by studying the culture of people within a College of Engineering. Such an approach was important as it helped us understand the context in which innovative changes might take place. Our work adds to the theories related to adoption and diffusion of engineering education innovations, change management, and attitudinal-behavioral theories. Results from this work will aid in promoting the realignment of individual faculty member and institutional priorities with those of the larger engineering community. The gap over the ‘valley of death’ in engineering education innovation, where innovations are discovered and vetted, but not widely implemented, will be bridged when these priorities are aligned. This project serves as the foundation on which a complete bridge can be built.

This work also provided much needed benchmarking for continued research in the area of engineering education transformation. The American Society for Engineering Education and the National Academy of Engineering have already defined their visions for the direction of engineering education. This project provides insights into current practice and identifies obstacles to overcome in moving forward. Teaching becomes more all-inclusive and participation in engineering is likely to broaden and include more underrepresented groups, benefiting society as a whole, when engineering education research is widely adopted in the classroom. 

Key findings from this work include:
* Pre-tenured faculty members seem to be more willing to innovate in their classrooms.
* Number of courses taught per year, years of college teaching experience, and age do not seem to be correlated with knowledge of innovations in engineering education or willingness to innovate.
* Using teaching innovations must be perceived as part of the work culture in order to be widely implemented.
* Student perceptions of faculty member willingness to use engineering education innovations in the classroom confirmed data collected by faculty in self-reports. In other words, students can accurately judge how willing his/her professor is to innovate in the classroom.
* Innovations in teaching were specifically mentioned in promotion and tenure policies as being valued for candidates for tenure and promotion, but faculty workload and evaluation policies and procedures did not reflect this. This sent a mixed message to faculty members and influenced their perceptions about whether or not implementing teaching innovations is valued.

Results from this project can help promote the creation of a culture within a university that values innovation in the classroom by bringing awareness to administrations of the disconnect between stated policies and faculty member perceptions.
